annotations.1: [Psalm 89] The community laments the defeat of the Davidic king, to whom God promised kingship as enduring as the heavens ( Psalm 89:2-5). The psalm narrates how God became king of the divine beings ( Psalm 89:6-9) and how the Davidic king became king of earthly kings ( Psalm 89:20-38). Since the defeat of the king calls into question God's promise, the community ardently prays God to be faithful to the original promise to David ( Psalm 89:39-52).
annotations.2: [3-5] David's dynasty is to be as long-lasting as the heavens, a statement reinforced by using the same verbs (establish, stand) both of the divine love and loyalty and of the Davidic dynasty and throne. Cf Psalm 89:29-30
annotations.3: [7] The gods: literally, "the sons of gods," "the holy ones" and "courtiers" of Psalm 89:6, 8. These heavenly spirits are members of God's court
annotations.4: [11] Rahab: a mythological sea monster whose name is used in the Bible mainly as a personification of primeval chaos. Cf Job 9:13; 26:12; Psalm 74:13-14; Isaiah 51:9
annotations.5: [13] Zaphon and Amanus: two sacred mountains in northern Syria. Tabor: a high hill in the valley of Jezreel in northern Israel. Hermon: a mountain in Lebanon, forming the southern spur of the Anti-Lebanon range
annotations.6: [18,25] Horn: a concrete noun for an abstract quality; horn is a symbol of strength
annotations.7: [26] The sea . . . the rivers: geographically the limits of the Davidic Empire (the Mediterranean and the Euphrates); mythologically, the traditional forces of chaos. See note on Psalm 89:11
annotations.8: [28] Most High: a divine title, which is here extended to David as God's own king. Cf Psalm 2:7-9; Isaiah 9:5. As God rules over the members of the heavenly council ( Psalm 89:6-9), so David, God's surrogate, rules over earthly kings
annotations.9: [37-38] Like the sun before me . . . like the sky: as enduring as the heavenly lights. Cf Psalm 89:2-5 and Psalm 72:5, 17
annotations.10: [53] The doxology at the end of the third book of the Psalms; it is not part of Psalm 89

1.verse: For the leader. A psalm of David,

2.verse: when Nathan the prophet came to him after his affair with Bathsheba.

3.verse: Have mercy on me, God, in your goodness; in your abundant compassion blot out my offense.

4.verse: Wash away all my guilt; from my sin cleanse me.

5.verse: For I know my offense; my sin is always before me.

6.verse: Against you alone have I sinned; I have done such evil in your sight That you are just in your sentence, blameless when you condemn.

7.verse: True, I was born guilty, a sinner, even as my mother conceived me.

8.verse: Still, you insist on sincerity of heart; in my inmost being teach me wisdom.

9.verse: Cleanse me with hyssop, that I may be pure; wash me, make me whiter than snow.

10.verse: Let me hear sounds of joy and gladness; let the bones you have crushed rejoice.

11.verse: Turn away your face from my sins; blot out all my guilt.

12.verse: A clean heart create for me, God; renew in me a steadfast spirit.

13.verse: Do not drive me from your presence, nor take from me your holy spirit.

14.verse: Restore my joy in your salvation; sustain in me a willing spirit.

15.verse: I will teach the wicked your ways, that sinners may return to you.

16.verse: Rescue me from death, God, my saving God, that my tongue may praise your healing power.

17.verse: Lord, open my lips; my mouth will proclaim your praise.

18.verse: For you do not desire sacrifice; a burnt offering you would not accept.

19.verse: My sacrifice, God, is a broken spirit; God, do not spurn a broken, humbled heart.

20.verse: Make Zion prosper in your good pleasure; rebuild the walls of Jerusalem.

21.verse: Then you will be pleased with proper sacrifice, burnt offerings and holocausts; then bullocks will be offered on your altar.

annotations.1: [Psalm 51] A lament, the most famous of the seven Penitential Psalms, prays for the removal of the personal and social disorders that sin has brought. The poem has two parts of approximately equal length: Psalm 51:3-10 and Psalm 51:11-19, and a conclusion in Psalm 51:20-21. The two parts interlock by repetition of "blot out" in the first verse of each section ( Psalm 51:3, 11), of "wash (away)" just after the first verse of each section ( Psalm 51:4) and just before the last verse ( Psalm 51:9) of the first section, and of "heart," "God," and "spirit" in Psalm 51:12, 19. The first part ( Psalm 51:3-10) asks deliverance from sin, which is not just a past act but its emotional, physical, and social consequences. The second part ( Psalm 51:11-19) seeks something more profound than wiping the slate clean: nearness to God, living by the spirit of God ( Psalm 51:12-13), like the relation between God and people described in Jeremiah 31:33-34. Nearness to God brings joy and the authority to teach sinners ( Psalm 51:15-16). Such proclamation is better than offering sacrifice ( Psalm 51:17-19). The last two verses ask for the rebuilding of Jerusalem ( Psalm 51:19 [20-21]).
annotations.2: [7] A sinner, even as my mother conceived me: literally, "In iniquity was I conceived," an instance of hyperbole: at no time was the psalmist ever without sin. Cf Psalm 88:15, "I am mortally afflicted since youth," i.e., I have always been afflicted. The verse does not imply that the sexual act of conception is sinful
annotations.3: [9] Hyssop: a small bush whose many woody twigs make a natural sprinkler. It was prescribed in the Mosaic law as an instrument for sprinkling sacrificial blood or lustral water for cleansing. Cf Exodus 12:22; Lev 14:4; Numbers 19:18
annotations.4: [18] For you do not desire sacrifice: the mere offering of the ritual sacrifice apart from good dispositions is not acceptable to God. Cf Psalm 50
annotations.5: [19(20-21)] Most scholars think that these verses were added to the psalm some time after the destruction of the temple in 587 B.C. The verses assume that the rebuilt temple will be an ideal site for national reconciliation

1.verse: For the leader. A psalm of David.

2.verse: Happy those concerned for the lowly and poor; when misfortune strikes, the LORD delivers them.

3.verse: The LORD keeps and preserves them, makes them happy in the land, and does not betray them to their enemies.

4.verse: The LORD sustains them on their sickbed, allays the malady when they are ill.

5.verse: Once I prayed, "LORD, have mercy on me; heal me, I have sinned against you.

6.verse: My enemies say the worst of me: 'When will that one die and be forgotten?'

7.verse: When people come to visit me, they speak without sincerity. Their hearts store up malice; they leave and spread their vicious lies.

8.verse: My foes all whisper against me; they imagine the worst about me:

9.verse: I have a deadly disease, they say; I will never rise from my sickbed.

10.verse: Even the friend who had my trust, who shared my table, has scorned me.

11.verse: But you, LORD, have mercy and raise me up that I may repay them as they deserve."

12.verse: By this I know you are pleased with me, that my enemy no longer jeers at me.

13.verse: For my integrity you have supported me and let me stand in your presence forever.

14.verse: Blessed be the LORD, the God of Israel, from all eternity and forever. Amen. Amen.

annotations.1: [Psalm 41] A thanksgiving for rescue from illness ( Psalm 41:4, 5, 9). Many people, even friends, have interpreted the illness as a divine punishment for sin and have ostracized the psalmist ( Psalm 41:5-11). The healing shows the return of God's favor and rebukes the psalmist's detractors ( Psalm 41:12-13).
annotations.2: [2] Happy those concerned for the lowly and poor: other psalms use the same formula ("Happy those") for those whom God favors. Cf Psalm 32:1-2; 34:9; 40:5; 65:5. The psalmist's statement about God's love of the poor is based on the experience of being rescued ( Psalm 41:1-3)
annotations.3: [10] Even the friend . . . has scorned me: John 13:18 cites this verse to characterize Judas as a false friend. Scorned me: an interpretation of the unclear Hebrew, "made great the heel against me.&quot
annotations.4: [11] That I may repay them as they deserve: the healing itself is an act of judgment through which God decides for the psalmist and against the false friends. The prayer is not necessarily for strength to punish enemies
annotations.5: [14] The doxology, not part of the psalm, marks the end of the first of the five books of the Psalter. Compare Psalm 72:18-20; 89:53; 106:48

1.verse: A song of ascents. Of David. I Had not the LORD been with us, let Israel say,

2.verse: Had not the LORD been with us, when people rose against us,

3.verse: They would have swallowed us alive, for their fury blazed against us.

4.verse: The waters would have engulfed us, the torrent overwhelmed us;

5.verse: seething waters would have drowned us.

6.verse: Blessed be the LORD, who did not leave us to be torn by their fangs.

7.verse: We escaped with our lives like a bird from the fowler's snare; the snare was broken and we escaped.

8.verse: Our help is the name of the LORD, the maker of heaven and earth

annotations.1: [Psalm 124] A thanksgiving which teaches that Israel's very existence is owed to God who rescues them. In the first part Israel's enemies are compared to the mythic sea dragon ( Psalm 124:2b-3a; cf Jeremiah 51:34) and Flood ( Psalm 124:3b-5; cf Isaiah 51:9-10). The psalm heightens the malice of human enemies by linking them to the primordial enemies of God's creation. Israel is a bird freed from the trapper's snare ( Psalm 124:6-8) - freed originally from Pharaoh and now from the current danger.
annotations.2: [8] Our help is the name: for the idiom, see Exodus 18:4

1.verse: For the leader. A maskil of the Korahites.

2.verse: O God, we have heard with our own ears; our ancestors have told us The deeds you did in their days, with your own hand in days of old:

3.verse: You rooted out nations to plant them, crushed peoples to make room for them.

4.verse: Not with their own swords did they conquer the land, nor did their own arms bring victory; It was your right hand, your own arm, the light of your face for you favored them.

5.verse: You are my king and my God, who bestows victories on Jacob.

6.verse: Through you we batter our foes; through your name, trample our adversaries.

7.verse: Not in my bow do I trust, nor does my sword bring me victory.

8.verse: You have brought us victory over our enemies, shamed those who hate us.

9.verse: In God we have boasted all the day long; your name we will praise forever. Selah

10.verse: But now you have rejected and disgraced us; you do not march out with our armies.

11.verse: You make us retreat before the foe; those who hate us plunder us at will.

12.verse: You hand us over like sheep to be slaughtered, scatter us among the nations.

13.verse: You sell your people for nothing; you make no profit from their sale.

14.verse: You make us the reproach of our neighbors, the mockery and scorn of those around us.

15.verse: You make us a byword among the nations; the peoples shake their heads at us.

16.verse: All day long my disgrace is before me; shame has covered my face

17.verse: At the sound of those who taunt and revile, at the sight of the spiteful enemy.

18.verse: All this has come upon us, though we have not forgotten you, nor been disloyal to your covenant.

19.verse: Our hearts have not turned back, nor have our steps strayed from your path.

20.verse: Yet you have left us crushed, desolate in a place of jackals; you have covered us with darkness.

21.verse: If we had forgotten the name of our God, stretched out our hands to another god,

22.verse: Would not God have discovered this, God who knows the secrets of the heart?

23.verse: For you we are slain all the day long, considered only as sheep to be slaughtered.

24.verse: Awake! Why do you sleep, O Lord? Rise up! Do not reject us forever!

25.verse: Why do you hide your face; why forget our pain and misery?

26.verse: We are bowed down to the ground; our bodies are pressed to the earth.

27.verse: Rise up, help us! Redeem us as your love demands.

annotations.1: [Psalm 44] In this lament the community reminds God of past favors which it has always acknowledged ( Psalm 44:2-9). But now God has abandoned Israel to defeat and humiliation ( Psalm 44:10-17), though the people are not conscious of any sin against the covenant ( Psalm 44:18-23). They struggle with being God's special people amid divine silence; yet they continue to pray ( Psalm 44:24-26).
annotations.2: [11] You make us retreat: the corollary of Psalm 44:3. Defeat, like victory, is God's doing; neither Israel nor its enemies can claim credit ( Psalm 44:23)
annotations.3: [19] Our hearts have not turned back: Israel's defeat was not caused by its lack of fidelity
annotations.4: [20] A place of jackals: following Israel's defeat and exile ( Psalm 44:11-12), the land lies desolate, inhabited only by jackals. Cf Isaiah 13:22; Jeremiah 9:10; 10:22. Others take tannim as "sea monster" (cf Ezekiel 29:3; 32:2) and render: "you crushed us as you did the sea monster.&quot

4.verse: May the peoples praise you, God; may all the peoples praise you!

6.verse: May the peoples praise you, God; may all the peoples praise you!

annotations.1: [Psalm 67] A petition for a bountiful harvest ( Psalm 67:7), made in the awareness that Israel's prosperity will persuade the nations to worship its God.
annotations.2: [2] May God be gracious to us: the people's petition echoes the blessing pronounced upon them by the priests. Cf Numbers 6:22-27

1.verse: A psalm of David. The LORD is my shepherd; there is nothing I lack.

2.verse: In green pastures you let me graze; to safe waters you lead me;

3.verse: you restore my strength. You guide me along the right path for the sake of your name.

4.verse: Even when I walk through a dark valley, I fear no harm for you are at my side; your rod and staff give me courage.

5.verse: You set a table before me as my enemies watch; You anoint my head with oil; my cup overflows.

6.verse: Only goodness and love will pursue me all the days of my life; I will dwell in the house of the LORD for years to come.

annotations.1: [Psalm 23] God's loving care for the psalmist is portrayed under the figures of a shepherd for the flock ( Psalm 23:1-4) and a host's generosity toward a guest ( Psalm 23:5-6). The imagery of both sections is drawn from traditions of the exodus ( Isaiah 40:11; 49:10; Jeremiah 31:10)
annotations.2: [1] My shepherd: God as good shepherd is common in both the Old Testament and the New Testament ( Ezekiel 34:11-16; John 10:11-18).
annotations.3: [3] The right path: connotes "right way" and "way of righteousness.&quot
annotations.4: [4] A dark valley: a different division of the Hebrew consonants yields the translation "the valley of the shadow of death.&quot
annotations.5: [5] You set a table before me: this expression occurs in an exodus context in Psalm 78:19. As my enemies watch: my enemies see that I am God's friend and guest. Oil: a perfumed ointment made from olive oil, used especially at banquets ( Psalm 104:15; Matthew 26:7; Luke 7:37, 46; John 12:2)
annotations.6: [6] Goodness and love: the blessings of God's covenant with Israel

1.verse: A psalm of Asaph. The LORD, the God of gods, has spoken and summoned the earth from the rising of the sun to its setting.

2.verse: From Zion God shines forth. perfect in beauty.

3.verse: Our God comes and will not be silent! Devouring fire precedes, storming fiercely round about.

4.verse: God summons the heavens above and the earth to the judgment of his people:

5.verse: "Gather my faithful ones before me, those who made a covenant with me by sacrifice."

6.verse: The heavens proclaim divine justice, for God alone is the judge. Selah

7.verse: "Listen, my people, I will speak; Israel, I will testify against you; God, your God, am I.

8.verse: Not for your sacrifices do I rebuke you, nor for your holocausts, set before me daily.

9.verse: I need no bullock from your house, no goats from your fold.

10.verse: For every animal of the forest is mine, beasts by the thousands on my mountains.

11.verse: I know every bird of the heavens; the creatures of the field belong to me.

12.verse: Were I hungry, I would not tell you, for mine is the world and all that fills it.

13.verse: Do I eat the flesh of bulls or drink the blood of goats?

14.verse: Offer praise as your sacrifice to God; fulfill your vows to the Most High.

15.verse: Then call on me in time of distress; I will rescue you, and you shall honor me."

16.verse: But to the wicked God says: "Why do you recite my commandments and profess my covenant with your lips?

17.verse: You hate discipline; you cast my words behind you!

18.verse: When you see thieves, you befriend them; with adulterers you throw in your lot.

19.verse: You give your mouth free rein for evil; you harness your tongue to deceit.

20.verse: You sit maligning your own kin, slandering the child of your own mother.

21.verse: When you do these things should I be silent? Or do you think that I am like you? I accuse you, I lay the charge before you.

22.verse: "Understand this, you who forget God, lest I attack you with no one to rescue.

23.verse: Those who offer praise as a sacrifice honor me; to the obedient I will show the salvation of God.&quot

annotations.1: [Psalm 50] A covenant lawsuit stating that the sacrifice God really wants is the sacrifice of praise accompanied by genuine obedience (cf Micah 6:1-8). It begins with a theophany and the summoning of the court ( Psalm 50:1-6). Then in direct address God explains what is required of the faithful ( Psalm 50:7-15), rebukes the hypocritical worshiper ( Psalm 50:16-21), and concludes with a threat and a promise ( Psalm 50:22-23; cf Isaiah 1:19-20).

1.verse: A psalm of Asaph. God rises in the divine council, gives judgment in the midst of the gods.

2.verse: "How long will you judge unjustly and favor the cause of the wicked? Selah

3.verse: Defend the lowly and fatherless; render justice to the afflicted and needy.

4.verse: Rescue the lowly and poor; deliver them from the hand of the wicked."

5.verse: The gods neither know nor understand, wandering about in darkness, and all the world's foundations shake.

6.verse: I declare: "Gods though you be, offspring of the Most High all of you,

7.verse: Yet like any mortal you shall die; like any prince you shall fall."

8.verse: Arise, O God, judge the earth, for yours are all the nations

annotations.1: [Psalm 82] As in Psalm 58, the pagan gods are seen as subordinate divine beings to whom Israel's God had delegated oversight of the foreign countries in the beginning ( Deut 32:8-9). Now God arises in the heavenly assembly ( Psalm 82:1) to rebuke the unjust "gods" ( Psalm 82:2-4), who are stripped of divine status and reduced in rank to mortals ( Psalm 82:5-7). They are accused of misruling the earth by not upholding the poor. A short prayer for universal justice concludes the psalm ( Psalm 82:8).
annotations.2: [5] The gods are blind and unable to declare what is right. Their misrule shakes earth's foundations (cf Psalm 11:3; 75:4), which God made firm in creation ( Psalm 96:10)
annotations.3: [6] I declare: "Gods though you be": in John 10:34 Jesus uses the verse to prove that those to whom the word of God is addressed can fittingly be called "gods.&quot
annotations.4: [8] Judge the earth: according to Deut 32:8-9, Israel's God had originally assigned jurisdiction over the foreign nations to the subordinate deities, keeping Israel as a personal possession. Now God will directly take over the rulership of the whole world

1.verse: A song; a psalm of Asaph.

2.verse: God, do not be silent; God, be not still and unmoved!

3.verse: See how your enemies rage; your foes proudly raise their heads.

4.verse: They conspire against your people, plot against those you protect.

5.verse: They say, "Come, let us wipe out their nation; let Israel's name be mentioned no more!"

6.verse: They scheme with one mind, in league against you:

7.verse: The tents of Ishmael and Edom, the people of Moab and Hagar,

8.verse: Gebal, Ammon, and Amalek, Philistia and the inhabitants of Tyre.

9.verse: Assyria, too, in league with them gives aid to the descendants of Lot. Selah

10.verse: Deal with them as with Midian; as with Sisera and Jabin at the torrent Kishon,

11.verse: Those destroyed at Endor, who became dung for the ground.

12.verse: Make their nobles like Oreb and Zeeb, all their princes like Zebah and Zalmunna,

13.verse: Who made a plan together, "Let us seize the pastures of God."

14.verse: My God, turn them into withered grass, into chaff flying before the wind.

15.verse: As a fire raging through a forest, a flame setting mountains ablaze,

16.verse: Pursue them with your tempest; terrify them with your storm.

17.verse: Cover their faces with shame, till they pay you homage, LORD.

18.verse: Let them be dismayed and shamed forever; let them perish in disgrace.

19.verse: Show them you alone are the LORD, the Most High over all the earth

annotations.1: [Psalm 83] The community lament complains to God of the nations' attempts to wipe out the name of Israel ( Psalm 83:1-8). The psalmist sees all Israel's enemies throughout its history united in a conspiracy ( Psalm 83:2-8). May God destroy the current crop of enemies as the enemies of old were destroyed ( Psalm 83:9-12), and may they be pursued until they acknowledge the name of Israel's God ( Psalm 83:13-18).
annotations.2: [7-9] Apart from the Assyrians, all the nations listed here were neighbors of Israel. The people of . . . Hagar: a tribe of the desert regions east of Ammon and Moab ( 1 Chron 5:10, 19-22). Gebal is the Phoenician city of Byblos or perhaps a mountain region south of the Dead Sea. The descendants of Lot are Moab and Edom ( Genesis 19:36-38 and Deut 2:9). These nations were never united against Israel in the same period; the psalm has lumped them all together
annotations.3: [10-13] For the historical events, see Jdgs 4-8

1.verse: For the leader; with stringed instruments. Of David.

2.verse: Hear my cry, O God, listen to my prayer!

3.verse: From the brink of Sheol I call; my heart grows faint. Raise me up, set me on a rock,

4.verse: for you are my refuge, a tower of strength against the foe.

5.verse: Then I will ever dwell in your tent, take refuge in the shelter of your wings. Selah

7.verse: "Add to the days of the king's life; may his years be many generations;

8.verse: May he reign before God forever; may your love and fidelity preserve him" -

9.verse: Then I will sing your name forever, fulfill my vows day after day

annotations.1: [Psalm 61] A lament of the king who feels himself at the brink of death ( Psalm 61:3) and cries out for the strong and saving presence of God ( Psalm 61:3b-5). The king cites the prayer being made for him ( Psalm 61:7-8), and promises to give thanks to God.
annotations.2: [3] Brink of Sheol: literally, "edge of the earth," "earth" being taken in its occasional meaning "the underworld." Cf Jonah 2:3
annotations.3: [6] In prayer: added for sense. Psalm 61:7-8 express the plea of Psalm 61:6
annotations.4: [9] Then: Hebrew "just as," i.e., in accord with the vows referred to in Psalm 61:5

1.verse: Rejoice, you just, in the LORD; praise from the upright is fitting.

2.verse: Give thanks to the LORD on the harp; on the ten-stringed lyre offer praise.

3.verse: Sing to God a new song; skillfully play with joyful chant.

4.verse: For the LORD'S word is true; all his works are trustworthy.

5.verse: The LORD loves justice and right and fills the earth with goodness.

6.verse: By the LORD'S word the heavens were made; by the breath of his mouth all their host.

7.verse: The waters of the sea were gathered as in a bowl; in cellars the deep was confined.

8.verse: Let all the earth fear the LORD; let all who dwell in the world show reverence.

9.verse: For he spoke, and it came to be, commanded, and it stood in place.

10.verse: The LORD foils the plan of nations, frustrates the designs of peoples.

11.verse: But the plan of the LORD stands forever, wise designs through all generations.

12.verse: Happy the nation whose God is the LORD, the people chosen as his very own.

13.verse: From heaven the LORD looks down and observes the whole human race,

14.verse: Surveying from the royal throne all who dwell on earth.

15.verse: The one who fashioned the hearts of them all knows all their works.

16.verse: A king is not saved by a mighty army, nor a warrior delivered by great strength.

17.verse: Useless is the horse for safety; its great strength, no sure escape.

18.verse: But the LORD'S eyes are upon the reverent, upon those who hope for his gracious help,

19.verse: Delivering them from death, keeping them alive in times of famine.

20.verse: Our soul waits for the LORD, who is our help and shield.

21.verse: For in God our hearts rejoice; in your holy name we trust.

22.verse: May your kindness, LORD, be upon us; we have put our hope in you.

annotations.1: [Psalm 33] A hymn in which the just are invited ( Psalm 33:1-3) to praise God, who by a mere word ( Psalm 33:4-5) created the three-tiered universe of the heavens, the cosmic waters, and the earth ( Psalm 33:6-9). Human words, in contrast, effect nothing ( Psalm 33:10-11). The greatness of human beings consists in God's choosing them as a special people and their faithful response ( Psalm 33:12-22).
annotations.2: [6] All their host: the stars of the sky are commonly viewed as a vast army, e.g., Nehemiah 9:6; Isaiah 40:26; 45:12; Jeremiah 33:22
annotations.3: [7] The waters . . . as in a bowl: ancients sometimes attributed the power keeping the seas from overwhelming land to a primordial victory of the storm-god over personified Sea. God confines the seas as easily as one puts water in a bowl

1.verse: The LORD is king, the peoples tremble; God is enthroned on the cherubim, the earth quakes.

2.verse: The LORD is great on Zion, exalted above all the peoples.

3.verse: Let them praise your great and awesome name: Holy is God!

4.verse: O mighty king, lover of justice, you alone have established fairness; you have created just rule in Jacob.

5.verse: Exalt the LORD, our God; bow down before his footstool; holy is God!

6.verse: Moses and Aaron were among his priests, Samuel among those who called on God's name; they called on the LORD, who answered them.

7.verse: From the pillar of cloud God spoke to them; they kept the decrees, the law they received.

8.verse: O LORD, our God, you answered them; you were a forgiving God, though you punished their offenses.

9.verse: Exalt the LORD, our God; bow down before his holy mountain; holy is the LORD, our God

annotations.1: [Psalm 99] A hymn to God as the king whose grandeur is most clearly seen on Mount Zion ( Psalm 99:2) and in the laws given to Israel ( Psalm 99:4). Israel is special because of God's word of justice, which was mediated by the revered speakers, Moses, Aaron, and Samuel ( Psalm 99:6-8). The poem is structured by the threefold statement that God is holy ( Psalm 99:3, 5, 9) and by the twice-repeated command to praise ( Psalm 99:5, 9)
annotations.2: [1] Enthroned on the cherubim: cherubim were composite beings with animal and human features, common in ancient Near Eastern art. annotations.1: [Psalm 81] At a pilgrimage feast, probably harvest in the fall, the people assemble in the temple in accord with the Sinai ordinances ( Psalm 81:2-6). annotations.2: [1] Upon the gittith: probably the title of the melody to which the psalm was to be sung or a musical instrument.
annotations.3: [4] New moon . . . full moon: the pilgrimage feast of harvest began with a great assembly ( Lev 23:24; Numbers 29:1), used the new moon as a sign ( Numbers 29:6), and included trumpets ( Lev 23:24)
annotations.4: [6] I hear a new oracle: literally, "a tongue I do not know I hear." A temple official speaks the word of God ( Psalm 81:5b-16), which is authoritative and unlike merely human words (cf Numbers 24:4, 16)
annotations.5: [7] I relieved their shoulders of the burden: literally, "his [Israel's] shoulder," hence the plural translation. A reference to the liberation of Israel from slavery in Egypt. The basket: for carrying clay to make bricks. Cf Exodus 1:14
annotations.6: [8] Meribah: place of rebellion in the wilderness; cf Exodus 17:7; Numbers 20:13
annotations.7: [10] There must be no foreign god among you: as in Psalm 50 and 95, Israel is challenged to obey the first commandment of fidelity to God after the proclamation of the exodus

annotations.1: [Psalm 68] The psalm is extremely difficult because the Hebrew text is badly preserved and the ceremony that it describes is uncertain. The translation assumes the psalm accompanied the early autumn Feast of Tabernacles (Sukkoth), which included a procession of the tribes ( Psalm 68:25-28). Israel was being oppressed by a foreign power, perhaps Egypt ( Psalm 68:31-32) - unless Egypt stands for any oppressor. The psalm may have been composed from segments of ancient poems, which would explain why the transitions are implied rather than explicitly stated. At any rate, Psalm 68:2 is based on Numbers 10:35-36, and Psalm 68:8-9 are derived from Judges 5:4-5. The argument develops in nine stanzas (each of three to five poetic lines): 1. confidence that God will destroy Israel's enemies ( Psalm 68:2-4); 2. call to praise God as savior ( Psalm 68:5-7); 3. God's initial rescue of Israel from Egypt ( Psalm 68:8), the Sinai encounter ( Psalm 68:9), and the settlement in Canaan ( Psalm 68:10-11); 4. the defeat of the Canaanite kings ( Psalm 68:12-15); 5. the taking of Jerusalem, where Israel's God will rule the world ( Psalm 68:16-19); 6. praise for God's past help and for the future interventions that will be modeled on the ancient exodus-conquest ( Psalm 68:20-24); 7. procession at the Feast of Tabernacles ( Psalm 68:25-28); 8. prayer that the defeated enemies bring tribute to the temple (29-32); 9. invitation for all kingdoms to praise Israel's God (33-35).
annotations.2: [2] The opening line alluding to Numbers 10:35 makes clear that God's assistance in the period of the exodus and conquest is the model and assurance of all future divine help
annotations.3: [5] Exalt the rider of the clouds: God's intervention is in the imagery of Canaanite myth in which the storm-god mounted the storm clouds to ride to battle. Such theophanies occur throughout the psalm: Psalm 68:2-3, 8-10, 12-15, 18-19, 22-24, 29-32, 34-35. See Deut 33:26; Psalm 18:8-16; Isaiah 19:1
annotations.4: [7] While rebels live in the desert: rebels must live in the arid desert, whereas God's people will live in the well-watered land ( Psalm 68:8-11)
annotations.5: [12-15] The Hebrew text upon which the translation is based has apparently suffered dislocation and has been substantially rearranged for sense. The version of the defeat of the kings differs from that in the book of Joshua, where the people play a significant role. Here God alone is responsible for the victory (though the actual battle is not described); Israel only gathers the spoils. God alone is the source of Israel's success; human effort is not important
annotations.6: [15] Zalmon: generally taken as the name of a mountain where snow is visible in winter, perhaps to be located in the Golan Heights or in the mountains of Bashan or Hauran east of the Sea of Galilee
annotations.7: [17] The mountain: Mount Zion, the site of the temple
annotations.8: [23] Even from Bashan . . . from the depths of the sea: the heights and the depths, the farthest places where enemies might flee
annotations.9: [25-28] Your procession: the procession renews God's original taking up of residence on Zion, described in Psalm 68:16-19
annotations.10: [31] The wild beast of the reeds: probably the Nile crocodile, a symbol for Egypt; see Psalm 68:32 and Ezekiel 29:2-5
annotations.11: [31] Psalm 68:32[29-30] Lower Egypt is the delta area north of Cairo. Upper Egypt is the Nile-Valley from Cairo to Aswan. Ethiopia is still further south

annotations.1: [Psalm 94] A lament of an individual who is threatened by wicked people. The danger affects the whole community. Calling upon God as judge ( Psalm 94:1-2), the psalm complains about oppression of the holy community by people within ( Psalm 94:3-7). Bold declarations of faith follow: denunciation of evildoers ( Psalm 94:8-11) and assurance to the just ( Psalm 94:12-15). annotations.1: [Psalm 27] Tradition has handed down the two sections of the psalm ( Psalm 27:1-6; 7-14) as one psalm, though each part could be understood as complete in itself. Asserting boundless hope that God will bring rescue ( Psalm 27:1-3), the psalmist longs for the presence of God in the temple, protection from all enemies ( Psalm 27:4-6). In part B there is a clear shift in tone ( Psalm 27:7-12); the climax of the poem comes with "I believe" ( Psalm 27:13), echoing "I trust" ( Psalm 27:3).
annotations.2: [2] To devour my flesh: the psalmist's enemies are rapacious beasts ( Psalm 7:3; 17:12; 22:14, 17)
annotations.3: [8] Seek God's face (literally: "to seek his face"): to commune with God in the temple. The idiom is derived from the practice of journeying to sacred places. Cf Hosea 5:15; 2 Sam 21:1; Psalm 24:6
annotations.4: [13] In the land of the living: or "in the land of life," an epithet of the Jerusalem temple ( Psalm 52:7; 116:9; Isaiah 38:11), where the faithful had access to the life-giving presence of God

annotations.1: [Psalm 150] The psalm is a closing doxology both for the fifth book of the Psalms (Psalm 150:107-149) and for the Psalter as a whole. Temple musicians and dancers are called to lead all beings on earth and in heaven in praise of God. The psalm proclaims to whom praise shall be given, and where ( Psalm 150:1); what praise shall be given, and why ( Psalm 150:2); how praise shall be given ( Psalm 150:3-5), and by whom ( Psalm 150:6)
annotations.2: [1] His holy sanctuary: God's temple on earth. The mighty dome of the heavens: literally, "[God's] strong vault"; heaven is here imagined as a giant plate separating the inhabited world from the waters of the heavens.

annotations.1: [Psalm 16] In the first section, the psalmist rejects the futile worship of false gods ( Psalm 16:2-5), preferring Israel's God ( Psalm 16:1), the giver of the land ( Psalm 16:6). The second section reflects on the wise and life-giving presence of God ( Psalm 16:7-11)
annotations.2: [1] Miktam: a term occurring six times in psalm superscriptions, always with "David." Its meaning is unknown.
annotations.3: [4] Take their names: to use the gods' names in oaths and hence to affirm them as one's own gods
annotations.4: [6] Pleasant places were measured out for me: the psalmist is pleased with the plot of land measured out to the family, which was to be passed on to succeeding generations ("my inheritance")

annotations.1: [1] The psalm may reflect a ceremony in which the king, as leader of the army, asked God's help ( Psalm 144:1-8). In Psalm 144:9 the poem shifts abruptly from pleading to thanksgiving, and (except for Psalm 144:11) shifts again to prayer for the people. The first section ( Psalm 144:1-2) is a prayer of thanks for victory; the second ( Psalm 144:3-7a), a humble acknowledgment of human nothingness and a supplication that God show forth saving power; the third ( Psalm 144:9-11), a promise of future thanksgiving; the fourth ( Psalm 144:12-15), a wish for prosperity and peace. A prayer for deliverance from treacherous foes serves as a refrain after the second and third sections ( Psalm 144:7b-8, 11). Except for its final section, the psalm is made up almost entirely of verses from other psalms

10.verse: The fear of the LORD is pure, enduring forever. The statutes of the LORD are true, all of them just;

annotations.1: [Psalm 19] The heavenly elements of the world, now beautifully arranged, bespeak the power and wisdom of their creator ( Psalm 19:2-7). The creator's wisdom is available to human beings in the law ( Psalm 19:8-11), toward which the psalmist prays to be open ( Psalm 19:12-14). The themes of light and speech unify the poem.
annotations.2: [4] No word or sound: the regular functioning of the heavens and the alternation of day and night inform humans without words of the creator's power and wisdom
annotations.3: [5] The sun: in other religious literature the sun is a judge and lawgiver since it sees all in its daily course; Psalm 19:5b-7 form a transition to the law in Psalm 19:8-11. The six synonyms for God's revelation ( Psalm 19:8-11) are applied to the sun in comparable literature
annotations.4: [12] Instructed: the Hebrew verb means both to shine and to teach. Cf Daniel 12:3

8.verse: "Will the Lord reject us forever, never again show favor?

annotations.1: [Psalm 77] A community lament in which the speaker ("I") describes the anguish of Israel at God's silence when its very existence is at stake ( Psalm 77:2-11). In response the speaker recites the story of how God brought the people into existence ( Psalm 77:12-20). The question is thus posed to God: Will you allow the people you created to be destroyed?
annotations.2: [11] I conclude: literally, "I said." The psalmist, after pondering the present distress and God's promises to Israel, has decided that God has forgotten the people
annotations.3: [12] I will remember: the verb sometimes means to make present the great deeds of Israel's past by reciting them. Cf Psalm 78:42; 105:5; 106:7

2.verse: Graciously rescue me, God! Come quickly to help me, LORD!

annotations.1: [2] Your holy place: the innermost part of the temple, the holy of holies, containing the ark. Cf 1 Kings 6:16, 19-23; 8:6-8.
annotations.2: [6] The psalmist shifts to fervent thanksgiving, probably responding to a priestly or prophetic oracle in Psalm 28:5cd (not usually transmitted) assuring the worshiper that the prayer has been heard

annotations.1: [Psalm 40] A thanksgiving ( Psalm 40:2-13) has been combined with a lament ( Psalm 40:14-17), that appears also in Psalm 70. The psalmist describes the rescue in spatial terms - being raised up from the swampy underworld to firm earth where one can praise God ( Psalm 40:2-4). All who trust God will experience like protection ( Psalm 40:5-6)! The psalm stipulates the precise mode of thanksgiving: not animal sacrifice but open and enthusiastic proclamation of the salvation just experienced ( Psalm 40:7-11). A prayer for protection concludes ( Psalm 40:12-17).
annotations.2: [4] A new song: a song in response to the new action of God (cf Psalm 33:3; 96:1; 144:9; 149:1; Isaiah 42:10). Giving thanks is not purely a human response but is itself a divine gift
annotations.3: [7-9] Obedience is better than sacrifice (cf 1 Sam 15:22; Isaiah 1:10-20; Hosea 6:6; Amos 5:22-25; Micah 6:6-8; Acts 7:42-43 [quoting Amos 5:25-26]). Hebrews 10:5-9 quotes the somewhat different Greek version and interprets it as Christ's self-oblation

1.verse: For the leader. A psalm of David. I LORD, you have probed me, you know me:

2.verse: you know when I sit and stand; you understand my thoughts from afar.

3.verse: My travels and my rest you mark; with all my ways you are familiar.

4.verse: Even before a word is on my tongue, LORD, you know it all.

5.verse: Behind and before you encircle me and rest your hand upon me.

6.verse: Such knowledge is beyond me, far too lofty for me to reach.

7.verse: Where can I hide from your spirit? From your presence, where can I flee?

8.verse: If I ascend to the heavens, you are there; if I lie down in Sheol, you are there too.

9.verse: If I fly with the wings of dawn and alight beyond the sea,

10.verse: Even there your hand will guide me, your right hand hold me fast.

11.verse: If I say, "Surely darkness shall hide me, and night shall be my light" -

12.verse: Darkness is not dark for you, and night shines as the day. Darkness and light are but one.

13.verse: You formed my inmost being; you knit me in my mother's womb.

14.verse: I praise you, so wonderfully you made me; wonderful are your works! My very self you knew;

15.verse: my bones were not hidden from you, When I was being made in secret, fashioned as in the depths of the earth.

16.verse: Your eyes foresaw my actions; in your book all are written down; my days were shaped, before one came to be.

17.verse: How precious to me are your designs, O God; how vast the sum of them!

18.verse: Were I to count, they would outnumber the sands; to finish, I would need eternity.

19.verse: If only you would destroy the wicked, O God, and the bloodthirsty would depart from me!

20.verse: Deceitfully they invoke your name; your foes swear faithless oaths.

21.verse: Do I not hate, LORD, those who hate you? Those who rise against you, do I not loathe?

22.verse: With fierce hatred I hate them, enemies I count as my own.

23.verse: Probe me, God, know my heart; try me, know my concerns.

24.verse: See if my way is crooked, then lead me in the ancient paths

annotations.1: [Psalm 139] A hymnic meditation on God's omnipresence and omniscience. The psalmist is keenly aware of God's all-knowing gaze ( Psalm 139:1-6), of God's presence in every part of the universe ( Psalm 139:7-12), and of God's control over the psalmist's very self ( Psalm 139:13-16). Summing up Psalm 139:1-16, 17-18 express wonder. There is only one place hostile to God's rule - wicked people. The psalmist prays to be removed from their company ( Psalm 139:19-24).
annotations.2: [2] When I sit and stand: in all my physical movement
annotations.3: [9] Fly with the wings of dawn: go to the extremities of the east. Beyond the sea: uttermost bounds of the west; the sea is the Mediterranean
annotations.4: [11] Night shall be my light: night to me is what day is to others
annotations.5: [15] The depths of the earth: figurative language for the womb, stressing the hidden and mysterious operations that occur there
annotations.6: [24] My way . . . the ancient paths: the manner of living of our ancestors, who were faithful to God's will. Cf Jeremiah 6:16

1.verse: Of David, when he feigned madness before Abimelech, who forced him to depart.

2.verse: I will bless the LORD at all times; praise shall be always in my mouth.

3.verse: My soul will glory in the LORD that the poor may hear and be glad.

4.verse: Magnify the LORD with me; let us exalt his name together.

5.verse: I sought the LORD, who answered me, delivered me from all my fears.

6.verse: Look to God that you may be radiant with joy and your faces may not blush for shame.

7.verse: In my misfortune I called, the LORD heard and saved me from all distress.

8.verse: The angel of the LORD, who encamps with them, delivers all who fear God.

9.verse: Learn to savor how good the LORD is; happy are those who take refuge in him.

10.verse: Fear the LORD, you holy ones; nothing is lacking to those who fear him.

11.verse: The powerful grow poor and hungry, but those who seek the LORD lack no good thing.

12.verse: Come, children, listen to me; I will teach you the fear of the LORD.

13.verse: Who among you loves life, takes delight in prosperous days?

14.verse: Keep your tongue from evil, your lips from speaking lies.

15.verse: Turn from evil and do good; seek peace and pursue it.

16.verse: The LORD has eyes for the just and ears for their cry.

17.verse: The LORD'S face is against evildoers to wipe out their memory from the earth.

18.verse: When the just cry out, the LORD hears and rescues them from all distress.

19.verse: The LORD is close to the brokenhearted, saves those whose spirit is crushed.

20.verse: Many are the troubles of the just, but the LORD delivers from them all.

21.verse: God watches over all their bones; not a one shall be broken.

22.verse: Evil will slay the wicked; those who hate the just are condemned.

23.verse: The LORD redeems loyal servants; no one is condemned whose refuge is God.

annotations.1: [Psalm 34] A thanksgiving in acrostic form, each line beginning with a successive letter of the Hebrew alphabet. In this psalm one letter is missing and two are in reverse order. The psalmist, fresh from the experience of being rescued ( Psalm 34:5, 7), can teach the "poor," those who are defenseless, to trust in God alone ( Psalm 34:4, 12). God will make them powerful ( Psalm 34:5-11) and give them protection ( Psalm 34:12-22)
annotations.2: [1] Abimelech: a scribal error for Achish. In 1 Sam 21:13-16, David feigned madness before Achish, not Abimelech.
annotations.3: [11] The powerful: literally, "lions." Fierce animals were sometimes metaphors for influential people
annotations.4: [12] Children: the customary term for students in Wisdom literature

1.verse: A song of ascents. The LORD answered me when I called in my distress:

2.verse: LORD, deliver me from lying lips, from treacherous tongues.

3.verse: What will the Lord inflict on you, O treacherous tongue, and what more besides?

4.verse: A warrior's sharpened arrows and fiery coals of brush wood!

5.verse: Alas, I was an alien in Meshech, I lived near the tents of Kedar!

6.verse: Too long did I live among those who hated peace.

7.verse: When I spoke of peace, they were for war

annotations.1: [Psalm 120] A thanksgiving, reporting divine rescue (Psalm 120:10) yet with fervent prayer for further protection against lying attackers ( Psalm 120:2-4). The psalmist is acutely conscious of living away from God's own land where divine peace prevails ( Psalm 120:5-7)
annotations.2: [1] Song of ascents: Psalm 120-134 all begin with this superscription. Most probably these fifteen psalms once formed a collection of psalms sung when pilgrims went to Jerusalem, since one "ascended" to Jerusalem ( 1 Kings 12:28; Psalm 24:3; 122:4; Luke 2:42) or to the house of God or to an altar ( 1 Kings 12:33; 2 Kings 23:2; Psalm 24:3). Less probable is the explanation that these psalms were sung by the exiles when they "ascended" to Jerusalem from Babylonia (cf Ezra 7:9). The idea, found in the Mishnah, that the fifteen steps on which the Levites sang corresponded to these fifteen psalms (Middot 2:5) must underlie the Vulgate translation canticum graduum, "song of the steps" or "gradual song."
annotations.3: [3] More besides: a common curse formula in Hebrew was "May the Lord do such and such evils to you [the evils being specified], and add still more to them." Cf 1 Sam 3:17; 14:44; 25:22. Here the psalmist is at a loss for a suitable malediction
annotations.4: [4] Coals of brushwood: coals made from the stalk of the broom plant burn with intense heat. The psalmist thinks of lighted coals cast at his enemies
annotations.5: [5] Meshech was in the far north ( Genesis 10:2) and Kedar was a tribe of the north Arabian desert ( Genesis 25:13). The psalmist may be thinking generally of all aliens living among inhospitable peoples

1.verse: For the leader; al Jeduthun. A psalm of David.

2.verse: My soul rests in God alone, from whom comes my salvation.

3.verse: God alone is my rock and salvation, my secure height; I shall never fall.

4.verse: How long will you set upon people, all of you beating them down, As though they were a sagging fence or a battered wall?

5.verse: Even from my place on high they plot to dislodge me. They delight in lies; they bless with their mouths, but inwardly they curse. Selah

6.verse: My soul, be at rest in God alone, from whom comes my hope.

7.verse: God alone is my rock and my salvation, my secure height; I shall not fall.

8.verse: My safety and glory are with God, my strong rock and refuge.

9.verse: Trust God at all times, my people! Pour out your hearts to God our refuge! Selah

10.verse: Mortals are a mere breath, the powerful but an illusion; On a balance they rise; together they are lighter than air.

11.verse: Do not trust in extortion; in plunder put no empty hope. Though wealth increase, do not set your heart upon it.

12.verse: One thing God has said; two things I have heard: Power belongs to God;

13.verse: ) so too, Lord, does kindness, And you render to each of us according to our deeds

annotations.1: [Psalm 62] A song of trust displaying serenity from experiencing God's power (the refrains of Psalm 62:2-3 and Psalm 62:6-7) and anger toward unjust enemies ( Psalm 62:4-5). From the experience of being rescued, the psalmist can teach others to trust in God ( Psalm 62:9-12)
annotations.2: [1] 'Al Jeduthun: apparently the Hebrew name for the melody.
annotations.3: [10] On a balance they rise: precious objects were weighed by balancing two pans suspended from a beam. The lighter pan rises
annotations.4: [12] One thing . . . two things: parallelism of numbers for the sake of variation, a common device in Semitic poetry. One should not literally add up the numbers. Cf Amos 1:3; Proverb 6:16-19; 30:15, 18, 21

1.verse: For the leader. Do not destroy! A psalm of Asaph; a song.

2.verse: We thank you, God, we give thanks; we call upon your name, declare your wonderful deeds. You said:

3.verse: "I will choose the time; I will judge fairly.

4.verse: The earth and all its inhabitants will quake, but I have firmly set its pillars." Selah

5.verse: So I say to the boastful: "Do not boast!" to the wicked: "Do not raise your horns!

6.verse: Do not raise your horns against heaven! Do not speak arrogantly against the Rock!"

7.verse: For judgment comes not from east or from west, not from the desert or from the mountains,

8.verse: But from God who decides, who brings some low and raises others high.

9.verse: Yes, a cup is in the LORD'S hand, foaming wine, fully spiced. When God pours it out, they will drain it even to the dregs; all the wicked of the earth must drink.

10.verse: But I will rejoice forever; I will sing praise to the God of Jacob,

11.verse: Who has said: "I will break off all the horns of the wicked, but the horns of the just shall be lifted up.&quot

annotations.1: [Psalm 75] The psalmist gives thanks and rejoices ( Psalm 75:2, 10) for the direct intervention of God, which is promised in two oracles (3-4,11). Expecting that divine intervention, the psalmist warns evildoers to repent ( Psalm 75:5-9).
annotations.2: [2] You said: supplied for clarity here and in Psalm 75:11. The translation assumes in both places that the psalmist is citing an oracle of God
annotations.3: [5] Do not raise your horns!: the horn is the symbol of strength; to raise one's horn is to exalt one's own power as Psalm 75:5 explains
annotations.4: A cup: "the cup of God's wrath" is the punishment inflicted on the wicked. Cf Isaiah 51:17; Jeremiah 25:15-29; 49:12; Ezekiel 23:31-33. Spiced: literally, "a mixed drink"; spices or drugs were added to wine. Cf Proverb 9:2, 5

1.verse: Hallelujah! Sing to the LORD a new song, a hymn in the assembly of the faithful.

2.verse: Let Israel be glad in their maker, the people of Zion rejoice in their king.

3.verse: Let them praise his name in festive dance, make music with tambourine and lyre.

4.verse: For the LORD takes delight in his people, honors the poor with victory.

5.verse: Let the faithful rejoice in their glory, cry out for joy at their banquet,

6.verse: With the praise of God in their mouths, and a two-edged sword in their hands,

7.verse: To bring retribution on the nations, punishment on the peoples,

8.verse: To bind their kings with chains, shackle their nobles with irons,

9.verse: To execute the judgments decreed for them - such is the glory of all God's faithful. Hallelujah

annotations.1: [Psalm 149] A hymn inviting the people of Israel to celebrate their God in song and festive dance ( Psalm 149:1-3, 5) because God has chosen them and given them victory ( Psalm 149:4). The exodus and conquest are the defining acts of Israel; the people must be ready to do again those acts in the future at the divine command ( Psalm 149:6-9).
annotations.2: [3] Make music with tambourine and lyre: the verse recalls the great exodus hymn of Exodus 15:20
annotations.3: [5] At their banquet: literally, "upon their couches." The people reclined to banquet
annotations.4: [9] The glory: what brings honor to the people is their readiness to carry out the divine will, here conceived as punishing injustice done by the nations

1.verse: Of Solomon.

2.verse: O God, give your judgment to the king; your justice to the son of kings; That he may govern your people with justice, your oppressed with right judgment,

3.verse: That the mountains may yield their bounty for the people, and the hills great abundance,

4.verse: That he may defend the oppressed among the people, save the poor and crush the oppressor.

5.verse: May he live as long as the sun endures, like the moon, through all generations.

6.verse: May he be like rain coming down upon the fields, like showers watering the earth,

7.verse: That abundance may flourish in his days, great bounty, till the moon be no more.

8.verse: May he rule from sea to sea, from the river to the ends of the earth.

9.verse: May his foes kneel before him, his enemies lick the dust.

10.verse: May the kings of Tarshish and the islands bring tribute, the kings of Arabia and Seba offer gifts.

11.verse: May all kings bow before him, all nations serve him.

12.verse: For he rescues the poor when they cry out, the oppressed who have no one to help.

13.verse: He shows pity to the needy and the poor and saves the lives of the poor.

14.verse: From extortion and violence he frees them, for precious is their blood in his sight.

15.verse: Long may he live, receiving gold from Arabia, prayed for without cease, blessed day by day.

16.verse: May wheat abound in the land, flourish even on the mountain heights. May his fruit increase like Lebanon's, his wheat like the grasses of the land.

17.verse: May his name be blessed forever; as long as the sun, may his name endure. May the tribes of the earth give blessings with his name; may all the nations regard him as favored.

18.verse: Blessed be the LORD, the God of Israel, who alone does wonderful deeds.

19.verse: Blessed be his glorious name forever; may all the earth be filled with the LORD'S glory. Amen and amen.

20.verse: The end of the psalms of David, son of Jesse.

annotations.1: [Psalm 72] A royal psalm in which the Israelite king, as the representative of God, is the instrument of divine justice ( Psalm 72:1-4, 12-14) and blessing ( Psalm 72:5-7, 15-17) for the whole world. The king is human, giving only what he has received from God. Hence intercession must be made for him. The extravagant language is typical of oriental royal courts
annotations.2: [2] The king . . . the son of kings: the crown prince is the king's son; the prayer envisages the dynasty.
annotations.3: [8] From sea to sea . . . the ends of the earth: the boundaries of the civilized world known at the time: from the Mediterranean Sea (the western sea) to the Persian Gulf (the eastern sea), and from the Euphrates (the river) to the islands and lands of southwestern Europe, "the ends of the earth." The words may also have a mythic nuance - the earth surrounded by cosmic waters, hence everywhere
annotations.4: [10] Tarshish and the islands: the far west ( Psalm 48:6); Arabia and Seba: the far south ( 1 Kings 10:1)
annotations.5: [14] Their blood: cf Psalm 116:15
annotations.6: [16] The translation of the difficult Hebrew is tentative
annotations.7: [17] May the tribes of the earth give blessing with his name: an echo of the promise to the ancestors ( Genesis 12:3; 26:4; 28:14), suggesting that the monarchy in Israel fulfilled the promise to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob
annotations.8: [18-19] A doxology marking the end of Book II of the Psalter

1.verse: For the leader; "upon the gittith." A psalm of David.

2.verse: O LORD, our Lord, how awesome is your name through all the earth! You have set your majesty above the heavens!

3.verse: Out of the mouths of babes and infants you have drawn a defense against your foes, to silence enemy and avenger.

4.verse: When I see your heavens, the work of your fingers, the moon and stars that you set in place -

5.verse: What are humans that you are mindful of them, mere mortals that you care for them?

6.verse: Yet you have made them little less than a god, crowned them with glory and honor.

7.verse: You have given them rule over the works of your hands, put all things at their feet:

8.verse: All sheep and oxen, even the beasts of the field,

9.verse: The birds of the air, the fish of the sea, and whatever swims the paths of the seas.

10.verse: O LORD, our Lord, how awesome is your name through all the earth!

annotations.1: [Psalm 8] While marvelling at the limitless grandeur of God ( Psalm 8:2-3), the psalmist is struck first by the smallness of human beings in creation ( Psalm 8:4-5), and then by the royal dignity and power that God has graciously bestowed upon them ( Psalm 8:6-9)
annotations.2: [1] Upon the gittith: probably the title of the melody to which the psalm was to be sung or a musical instrument.
annotations.3: [3] Babes and infants: the text is obscure. Some join this line to the last line of Psalm 8:2 (itself obscure) to read: "(you) whose majesty is exalted above the heavens / by the mouths of babes and infants." Drawn a defense: some prefer the Septuagint's "fashioned praise," which is quoted in Matthew 21:16. Enemy and avenger: probably cosmic enemies. The primeval powers of watery chaos are often personified in poetic texts ( Psalm 74:13-14; 89:11; Job 9:13; 26:12-13; Isaiah 51,9)
annotations.4: [5] Humans . . . mere mortals: literally, "(mortal) person". . . "son of man (in sense of a human being, Hebrew 'adam)." The emphasis is on the fragility and mortality of human beings to whom God has given great dignity
annotations.5: [6] Little less than a god: Hebrew 'elohim, the ordinary word for "God" or "the gods" or members of the heavenly court. The Greek version translated 'elohim by "angel, messenger"; several ancient and modern versions so translate. The meaning seems to be that God created human beings almost at the level of the beings in the heavenly world. Hebrews 2:9 finds the eminent fulfillment of this verse in Jesus Christ, who was humbled before being glorified. Cf also 1 Cor 15:27 where St. Paul applies to Christ the closing words of Psalm 8:7

1.verse: Bless the LORD, my soul! LORD, my God, you are great indeed! You are clothed with majesty and glory,

2.verse: robed in light as with a cloak. You spread out the heavens like a tent;

3.verse: you raised your palace upon the waters. You make the clouds your chariot; you travel on the wings of the wind.

4.verse: You make the winds your messengers; flaming fire, your ministers.

5.verse: You fixed the earth on its foundation, never to be moved.

6.verse: The ocean covered it like a garment; above the mountains stood the waters.

7.verse: At your roar they took flight; at the sound of your thunder they fled.

8.verse: They rushed up the mountains, down the valleys to the place you had fixed for them.

9.verse: You set a limit they cannot pass; never again will they cover the earth.

10.verse: You made springs flow into channels that wind among the mountains.

11.verse: They give drink to every beast of the field; here wild asses quench their thirst.

12.verse: Beside them the birds of heaven nest; among the branches they sing.

13.verse: You water the mountains from your palace; by your labor the earth abounds.

14.verse: You raise grass for the cattle and plants for our beasts of burden. You bring bread from the earth,

15.verse: and wine to gladden our hearts, Oil to make our faces gleam, food to build our strength.

16.verse: The trees of the LORD drink their fill, the cedars of Lebanon, which you planted.

17.verse: There the birds build their nests; junipers are the home of the stork.

18.verse: The high mountains are for wild goats; the rocky cliffs, a refuge for badgers.

19.verse: You made the moon to mark the seasons, the sun that knows the hour of its setting.

20.verse: You bring darkness and night falls, then all the beasts of the forest roam abroad.

21.verse: Young lions roar for prey; they seek their food from God.

22.verse: When the sun rises, they steal away and rest in their dens.

23.verse: People go forth to their work, to their labor till evening falls.

24.verse: How varied are your works, LORD! In wisdom you have wrought them all; the earth is full of your creatures.

25.verse: Look at the sea, great and wide! It teems with countless beings, living things both large and small.

26.verse: Here ships ply their course; here Leviathan, your creature, plays.

27.verse: All of these look to you to give them food in due time.

28.verse: When you give to them, they gather; when you open your hand, they are well filled.

29.verse: When you hide your face, they are lost. When you take away their breath, they perish and return to the dust from which they came.

30.verse: When you send forth your breath, they are created, and you renew the face of the earth.

31.verse: May the glory of the LORD endure forever; may the LORD be glad in these works!

32.verse: If God glares at the earth, it trembles; if God touches the mountains, they smoke!

33.verse: I will sing to the LORD all my life; I will sing praise to my God while I live.

34.verse: May my theme be pleasing to God; I will rejoice in the LORD.

35.verse: May sinners vanish from the earth, and the wicked be no more. Bless the LORD, my soul! Hallelujah

annotations.1: [Psalm 104] A hymn praising God who easily and skillfully made rampaging waters and primordial night into a world vibrant with life. The psalmist describes God's splendor in the heavens ( Psalm 104:1-4), how the chaotic waters were tamed to fertilize and feed the world ( 104:5-18), and how primordial night was made into a gentle time of refreshment ( Psalm 104:19-23). The picture is like Genesis 1:1-2: a dark and watery chaos is made dry and lighted so that creatures might live. The psalmist reacts to the beauty of creation with awe ( Psalm 104:24-34). May sin not deface God's work ( Psalm 104:35)!
annotations.2: [3] Your palace upon the waters: God's heavenly dwelling above the upper waters of the sky. Cf Genesis 1:6-7; Psalm 29:10
annotations.3: [5-9] God places the gigantic disk of the earth securely on its foundation and then, as a warrior, chases away the enveloping waters and confines them under, above, and around the earth
annotations.4: [16-18] Even the exotic flora and fauna of the high mountains of the Lebanon range receive adequate water
annotations.5: [26] Leviathan: a sea monster symbolizing primeval chaos. Cf Psalm 74:14; Isaiah 27:1; Job 40:25. God does not destroy chaos but makes it part of the created order
annotations.6: [29-30] On one level, the spirit (or wind) of God is the fall and winter rains that provide food for all creatures. On another, it is the breath (or spirit) of God that makes beings live
annotations.7: [35] Hallelujah: a frequent word in the last third of the Psalter. The word combines the plural imperative of praise (hallelu) with an abbreviated form of the divine name Yah(weh)

1.verse: A psalm of David. LORD, who may abide in your tent? Who may dwell on your holy mountain?

2.verse: IWhoever walks without blame, doing what is right, speaking truth from the heart;

3.verse: Who does not slander a neighbor, does no harm to another, never defames a friend;

4.verse: Who disdains the wicked, but honors those who fear the LORD; Who keeps an oath despite the cost,

5.verse: lends no money at interest, accepts no bribe against the innocent. III Whoever acts like this shall never be shaken.

annotations.1: [Psalm 15] The psalm records a liturgical scrutiny at the entrance to the temple court (cf Psalm 24:3-6; Isaiah 33:14b-16). The Israelite wishing to be admitted had to ask the temple official what conduct was appropriate to God's precincts. Note the emphasis on virtues relating to one's neighbor
annotations.2: [1] Your tent . . . your holy mountain: the temple could be referred to as "tent" ( Psalm 61:5; Isaiah 33:20), a reference to the tent of the wilderness period and the tent of David ( 2 Sam 6:17; 7:2), predecessors of the temple. Holy mountain: a venerable designation of the divine abode ( Psalm 2:6; 3:5; 43:3; 48:2 etc.).
annotations.3: [5] Lends no money at interest: lending money in the Old Testament was often seen as assistance to the poor in their distress, not as an investment; making money off the poor by charging interest was thus forbidden ( Exodus 22:24; Lev 25:36-37; Deut 23:20)

1.verse: For the leader. A psalm of David.

2.verse: Deliver me, LORD, from the wicked; preserve me from the violent,

3.verse: From those who plan evil in their hearts, who stir up conflicts every day,

4.verse: Who sharpen their tongues like serpents, venom of asps upon their lips. Selah

5.verse: Keep me, LORD, from the clutches of the wicked; preserve me from the violent, who plot to trip me up.

6.verse: The arrogant have set a trap for me; villains have spread a net, laid snares for me by the wayside. Selah

7.verse: I say to the LORD: You are my God; listen, LORD, to the words of my prayer.

8.verse: My revered LORD, my strong helper, my helmet on the day of battle.

9.verse: LORD, do not grant the desires of the wicked; do not let their plots succeed. Selah

10.verse: Around me they raise their proud heads; may the mischief they threaten overwhelm them.

11.verse: May God rain burning coals upon them, cast them into the grave never more to rise.

12.verse: Slanderers will not survive on earth; evil will quickly entrap the violent.

13.verse: For I know the LORD will secure justice for the needy, their rights for the poor.

14.verse: Then the just will give thanks to your name; the upright will dwell in your presence

annotations.1: [Psalm 140] A lament seeking rescue from violent and treacherous foes ( Psalm 140:2-6). The psalmist remains trusting ( Psalm 140:7-8), vigorously praying that the plans of the wicked recoil upon themselves ( Psalm 140:9-12). A serene statement of praise ends the psalm ( Psalm 140:13). The psalmist is content to be known as one of "the needy," "the poor," "the just," "the upright" ( Psalm 140:13), a class of people expecting divine protection.

annotations.3: [6] Have set a trap . . . have spread a net: the same figure, of hunters setting traps, occurs in Psalm 9:16; 31:5; 35:7; 64:6. Cf Matthew 22:15; Luke 11:54
